focus_skills: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A school newspaper surveys <math><mn>150</mn></math> randomly selected students at a school about whether they prefer to have longer lunch periods. Of those surveyed, <math><mn>60</mn><mo>%</mo></math> say they prefer longer lunch periods. Based on this sample, which of the following is the best estimate of the proportion of all students at the school who prefer longer lunch periods?
questions.explanation: Because the <math><mn>150</mn></math> students were randomly selected from the school, the sample proportion is an appropriate estimate for the population proportion. The sample proportion is <math><mn>60</mn><mo>%</mo></math>, or <math><mn>0.60</mn></math>, so <math><mn>0.60</mn></math> is the best estimate.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When a sample is random and reasonably large, use the sample proportion as the best point estimate for the population proportion.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A polling organization reports that, in a random sample of <math><mn>800</mn></math> adults in a city, <math><mn>68</mn><mo>%</mo></math> support a new public park, with a margin of error of <math><mo>±</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. Which of the following is the best interval for the percentage of all adults in the city who support the new public park?
questions.explanation: A margin of error of <math><mn>3</mn><mo>%</mo></math> means the population percentage is likely within <math><mn>3</mn></math> percentage points of the sample percentage. The sample result is <math><mn>68</mn><mo>%</mo></math>, so the interval is from <math><mn>68</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>65</mn><mo>%</mo></math> to <math><mn>68</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>71</mn><mo>%</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Interpret a margin of error by adding and subtracting it from the reported sample statistic to form an interval.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A researcher wants to estimate the proportion of residents in a town who regularly ride a bicycle to work. Which of the following sampling methods is most likely to produce a sample that is representative of all residents in the town?

options.A: Surveying people who are entering a bicycle shop in the town.
options.B: Surveying every tenth person listed in the town directory.
options.C: Surveying volunteers who respond to an online advertisement about biking.
options.D: Surveying people who are riding bicycles in a local park on a weekday morning.

questions.explanation: Surveying every tenth person in the town directory is close to a random sample of residents and is more representative than surveying people in places where biking is more common or using volunteers.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Prefer random or systematic sampling frames that cover the entire population over convenience or voluntary response sampling.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: In a random sample of <math><mn>200</mn></math> customers at a store, <math><mn>50</mn></math> customers say they used a digital coupon during their purchase. What is the sample proportion of customers who used a digital coupon? Express your answer as a decimal.
questions.explanation: The sample proportion is successes divided by total: <math><mfrac><mn>50</mn><mn>200</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.25</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Compute a sample proportion by dividing the count of successes by the sample size and then converting to the requested form.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A candidate for mayor is interested in the proportion of voters in a city who support a new transportation plan. Her staff surveys <math><mn>1000</mn></math> randomly selected registered voters and finds that <math><mn>54</mn><mo>%</mo></math> support the plan, with a margin of error of <math><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. Which of the following conclusions is most supported by the survey results?

options.A: Exactly <math><mn>54</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of voters in the city support the plan.
options.B: Between <math><mn>52</mn><mo>%</mo></math> and <math><mn>56</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of voters in the city support the plan.
options.C: Between <math><mn>50</mn><mo>%</mo></math> and <math><mn>58</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of voters in the city support the plan.
options.D: At least <math><mn>60</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of voters in the city support the plan.

questions.explanation: Add and subtract the margin of error from the estimate: <math><mn>54</mn><mo>%</mo><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>%</mo></math> gives <math><mn>52</mn><mo>%</mo></math> to <math><mn>56</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. This is a likely range for the population proportion, not an exact value.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When an estimate includes a margin of error, translate it into a lower and upper bound before choosing an answer choice.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: Two polling organizations each survey a random sample of adults in the same state about whether they support a proposed law. Organization X surveys <math><mn>400</mn></math> adults and reports that <math><mn>48</mn><mo>%</mo></math> support the law, with a margin of error of <math><mo>±</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. Organization Y surveys <math><mn>1600</mn></math> adults and reports that <math><mn>51</mn><mo>%</mo></math> support the law, with a margin of error of <math><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. Which statement is the best comparison of the two polls?

options.A: Poll X has the smaller margin of error because it surveyed fewer adults.
options.B: Poll X has the smaller margin of error because its sample percentage is closer to <math><mn>50</mn><mo>%</mo></math>.
options.C: Poll Y has the smaller margin of error because it surveyed more adults.
options.D: Poll Y has the smaller margin of error because its sample percentage is larger.

questions.explanation: With similar random sampling methods, a larger sample size generally yields a smaller margin of error. Organization Y surveyed <math><mn>1600</mn></math> adults (larger than <math><mn>400</mn></math>), so its reported margin of error is smaller.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To compare precision across surveys, focus on sample size and the reported margin of error, not the sample percentage.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A random sample of <math><mn>500</mn></math> households in a county shows that <math><mn>120</mn></math> of the households have a dog. The polling organization reports the result as <math><mn>24</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of households having a dog, with a margin of error of <math><mo>±</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. Which of the following statements is most consistent with this report?

options.A: It is certain that between <math><mn>20</mn><mo>%</mo></math> and <math><mn>28</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of all households in the county have a dog.
options.B: It is likely that between <math><mn>20</mn><mo>%</mo></math> and <math><mn>28</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of all households in the county have a dog.
options.C: Exactly <math><mn>24</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of all households in the county have a dog.
options.D: At least <math><mn>28</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of all households in the county have a dog.

questions.explanation: A margin of error creates a likely interval, not a guaranteed one. <math><mn>24</mn><mo>%</mo><mo>±</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>%</mo></math> gives <math><mn>20</mn><mo>%</mo></math> to <math><mn>28</mn><mo>%</mo></math> as a likely interval for the countywide proportion.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use probability language (like "likely") when interpreting margin-of-error intervals.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A random sample of <math><mn>250</mn></math> students at a university finds that <math><mn>175</mn></math> students prefer to study in the library rather than at home. The university reports this as an estimate for the proportion of all students who prefer to study in the library. What is this estimate, expressed as a percentage?
questions.explanation: The estimate is the sample proportion: <math><mfrac><mn>175</mn><mn>250</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.70</mn></math>, which is <math><mn>70</mn><mo>%</mo></math> as a percentage.
questions.score_improvement_tip: After computing a proportion, multiply by <math><mn>100</mn></math> to convert to a percent when requested.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A polling company reports that, in a random sample of adults nationwide, <math><mn>39</mn><mo>%</mo></math> say they get most of their news from online sources, with a margin of error of <math><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. Which of the following statements is best supported by these data?

options.A: Between <math><mn>37</mn><mo>%</mo></math> and <math><mn>41</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of the sampled adults say they get most of their news from online sources.
options.B: Between <math><mn>37</mn><mo>%</mo></math> and <math><mn>41</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of all adults nationwide say they get most of their news from online sources.
options.C: Exactly <math><mn>39</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of all adults nationwide say they get most of their news from online sources.
options.D: At least <math><mn>50</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of all adults nationwide say they get most of their news from online sources.

questions.explanation: The margin of error is used to infer a plausible interval for the population proportion. <math><mn>39</mn><mo>%</mo><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>%</mo></math> gives <math><mn>37</mn><mo>%</mo></math> to <math><mn>41</mn><mo>%</mo></math> as a plausible interval for all adults nationwide.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Tie the interval implied by the margin of error to the population described in the question, not to the specific people in the sample.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A sports columnist wants to estimate the proportion of fans who prefer evening games instead of afternoon games. The columnist considers four different sampling plans. Which plan is most likely to produce a representative sample of all fans of the team?

options.A: Survey fans who are at the stadium one hour before an evening game.
options.B: Survey fans who respond to a poll on the columnist’s social media page.
options.C: Survey every twentieth fan who purchases a ticket from the team’s official website over a week.
options.D: Survey fans who are watching an afternoon game at a local restaurant.

questions.explanation: Surveying every twentieth fan who purchases a ticket over a week is closer to a systematic sample from a broad list of fans and is more representative than convenience or voluntary response approaches.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Representative samples typically come from random or systematic selection from a broad sampling frame, not from volunteers or a single location/time.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: In a particular election, Candidate A and Candidate B are the only candidates. A polling firm surveys a random sample of <math><mn>2000</mn></math> likely voters. In the sample, <math><mn>51</mn><mo>%</mo></math> say they plan to vote for Candidate A and <math><mn>49</mn><mo>%</mo></math> say they plan to vote for Candidate B. The firm reports a margin of error of <math><mo>±</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. Which conclusion is most justified based on this poll?

options.A: Candidate A is certain to receive more votes than Candidate B.
options.B: Candidate B is certain to receive more votes than Candidate A.
options.C: Either candidate could receive more votes, because the poll’s margin of error means the true percentages could differ from the sample percentages.
options.D: The candidates are certain to receive exactly the same number of votes.

questions.explanation: With a margin of error of <math><mn>3</mn></math> percentage points, Candidate A’s support could plausibly be as low as <math><mn>48</mn><mo>%</mo></math> and Candidate B’s could plausibly be as high as <math><mn>52</mn><mo>%</mo></math>, so the intervals overlap. Because of this overlap, the poll does not justify certainty about the winner.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Check whether margin-of-error intervals overlap before concluding that one proportion is definitely larger than another.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A random sample of <math><mn>400</mn></math> voters in a region shows that <math><mn>260</mn></math> support a proposal. The margin of error for the estimate of the population proportion is reported as <math><mo>±</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. According to this report, what is the lower bound of the interval, in percent, for the percentage of all voters in the region who support the proposal?
questions.explanation: The sample proportion is <math><mfrac><mn>260</mn><mn>400</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.65</mn></math>, or <math><mn>65</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. Subtract <math><mn>4</mn></math> percentage points: <math><mn>65</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>61</mn></math>. The lower bound is <math><mn>61</mn><mo>%</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Convert the sample fraction to a percentage first, then apply the margin of error in percentage points.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A school district wants to estimate the proportion of all students in the district who participate in at least one extracurricular activity. The district plans to use a random sample of students and wants the margin of error to be no more than <math><mn>2</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. Which of the following changes to the study design would most directly reduce the margin of error of the estimate?

options.A: Decreasing the number of students in the sample.
options.B: Increasing the number of students in the sample.
options.C: Surveying only students who participate in extracurricular activities.
options.D: Surveying only students who do not participate in extracurricular activities.

questions.explanation: For random sampling, larger sample sizes produce more precise estimates and smaller margins of error. Decreasing sample size increases the margin of error, and restricting the sample to only certain students introduces bias rather than improving precision.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To reduce margin of error, increase the random sample size; don’t confuse a biased sample with a precise one.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A researcher conducts a survey to estimate the proportion of adults in a large city who drink coffee daily. In a random sample of <math><mn>900</mn></math> adults, <math><mn>63</mn><mo>%</mo></math> report drinking coffee daily. The researcher reports that the proportion of all adults in the city who drink coffee daily is <math><mn>63</mn><mo>%</mo></math> with a margin of error of <math><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. Which of the following statements about the population proportion is most accurate?

options.A: The population proportion must be exactly <math><mn>63</mn><mo>%</mo></math>.
options.B: The population proportion is guaranteed to be between <math><mn>59</mn><mo>%</mo></math> and <math><mn>67</mn><mo>%</mo></math>.
options.C: It is plausible that the population proportion is between <math><mn>61</mn><mo>%</mo></math> and <math><mn>65</mn><mo>%</mo></math>.
options.D: It is plausible that the population proportion is between <math><mn>61</mn><mo>%</mo></math> and <math><mn>65</mn><mo>%</mo></math>, but it could also be slightly outside that range.

questions.explanation: A margin of error indicates a likely interval, not a guarantee. <math><mn>63</mn><mo>%</mo><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>%</mo></math> suggests <math><mn>61</mn><mo>%</mo></math> to <math><mn>65</mn><mo>%</mo></math> is plausible, but there is still some chance the true proportion lies outside that range.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Distinguish between likely ranges and certainty; margin of error does not guarantee the parameter lies in the interval.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question:
A company wants to estimate the proportion of its customers who would be interested in a new subscription service. The company considers three different sampling plans.
Plan 1: Survey customers who visit the company’s website during one day.
Plan 2: Survey a simple random sample of customers from a list of all customers.
Plan 3: Survey customers who respond to an email invitation asking for feedback about the new service.
Which plan is most appropriate for making an inference about the proportion of all customers who would be interested in the new subscription service?

options.A: Plan <math><mn>1</mn></math>, because only current website visitors are likely to use the service.
options.B: Plan <math><mn>2</mn></math>, because a simple random sample of all customers is most representative.
options.C: Plan <math><mn>3</mn></math>, because customers who respond to the email are most interested in the service.
options.D: All three plans are equally appropriate for making an inference.

questions.explanation: Plan <math><mn>2</mn></math> is a simple random sample from the entire customer list, which is designed to be representative. Plans <math><mn>1</mn></math> and <math><mn>3</mn></math> are convenience/voluntary response samples and may be biased.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For population inferences, choose a sampling plan that gives all members of the population a chance to be selected.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: In a random sample of <math><mn>1600</mn></math> voters in a state, <math><mn>880</mn></math> say they support a ballot measure. The margin of error for the estimate of the population proportion is reported as <math><mo>±</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. What is the upper bound of the interval, in percent, for the percentage of all voters in the state who support the ballot measure?
questions.explanation: The sample proportion is <math><mfrac><mn>880</mn><mn>1600</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>0.55</mn></math>, or <math><mn>55</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. Add <math><mn>2</mn></math> percentage points to get the upper bound: <math><mn>55</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>57</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Compute the estimate, then apply the margin of error in percentage points to form the interval endpoints.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: Two surveys are conducted to estimate the proportion of students at a high school who bring their own lunch. Survey <math><mn>1</mn></math> uses a random sample of <math><mn>300</mn></math> students and has a margin of error of <math><mo>±</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. Survey <math><mn>2</mn></math> uses a random sample of <math><mn>1200</mn></math> students and has a margin of error of <math><mo>±</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. Both surveys find the same sample proportion of students who bring their own lunch. Which statement best explains why Survey <math><mn>2</mn></math> has a smaller margin of error?

options.A: Survey <math><mn>2</mn></math> has a smaller margin of error because it used a different question.
options.B: Survey <math><mn>2</mn></math> has a smaller margin of error because it used a larger random sample.
options.C: Survey <math><mn>2</mn></math> has a smaller margin of error because its sample proportion is closer to <math><mn>0</mn><mo>%</mo></math>.
options.D: Survey <math><mn>2</mn></math> has a smaller margin of error because it surveyed only students who bring their own lunch.

questions.explanation: With random sampling, increasing sample size reduces sampling variability and therefore reduces the margin of error. Survey <math><mn>2</mn></math> uses the larger sample (<math><mn>1200</mn></math>), so it has the smaller margin of error.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If sampling methods are comparable, the key driver of margin-of-error differences is usually sample size.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A survey of a random sample of college students at a large university finds that <math><mn>72</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of the sampled students have a part-time job, with a margin of error of <math><mo>±</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. The student newspaper claims, "At least three-fourths of all students at the university have a part-time job." Which of the following best explains whether the survey results support this claim?

options.A: The claim is supported because <math><mn>72</mn><mo>%</mo></math> is close to three-fourths.
options.B: The claim is supported because the margin of error is only <math><mn>4</mn><mo>%</mo></math>.
options.C: The claim is not supported because the upper bound of the interval is less than three-fourths.
options.D: The claim is not strongly supported because the plausible interval for the population proportion includes values below three-fourths.

questions.explanation: The margin-of-error interval is <math><mn>68</mn><mo>%</mo></math> to <math><mn>76</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. Because values below <math><mn>75</mn><mo>%</mo></math> are included, the claim that the population proportion is at least <math><mn>75</mn><mo>%</mo></math> is not strongly supported by the survey.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For "at least" claims, compare the claim to the entire interval: the lower bound must meet the claim to strongly support it.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A scientist wants to estimate the proportion of fish in a lake that are infected with a certain parasite. The scientist takes a random sample of <math><mn>400</mn></math> fish and finds that <math><mn>36</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of them are infected. The scientist reports an estimate for the proportion of all fish in the lake that are infected, with a margin of error of <math><mo>±</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. Which of the following is the best interpretation of this margin of error?

options.A: Exactly <math><mn>36</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of the fish in the lake are infected.
options.B: The proportion of infected fish in the sample is guaranteed to be between <math><mn>31</mn><mo>%</mo></math> and <math><mn>41</mn><mo>%</mo></math>.
options.C: The proportion of all fish in the lake that are infected is likely between <math><mn>31</mn><mo>%</mo></math> and <math><mn>41</mn><mo>%</mo></math>.
options.D: At least <math><mn>41</mn><mo>%</mo></math> of the fish in the lake are infected.

questions.explanation: The margin of error applies to the population proportion. <math><mn>36</mn><mo>%</mo><mo>±</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>%</mo></math> gives a likely interval from <math><mn>31</mn><mo>%</mo></math> to <math><mn>41</mn><mo>%</mo></math> for the proportion of all fish in the lake that are infected.
questions.score_improvement_tip: State the interval in terms of the population parameter whenever a margin of error is given.

questions.skill: Inference from sample statistics and margin of error
questions.question: A polling organization wants the margin of error for estimating a population proportion to be at most <math><mn>3</mn><mo>%</mo></math>. The organization plans to use a random sample from a large population and assumes that the true population proportion is about <math><mn>0.5</mn></math>. Using this assumption, the organization estimates that the required sample size is approximately <math><mn>1100</mn></math> people. Later, the organization decides to double the sample size. Using the same assumptions, what is the approximate new margin of error, in percent, for the estimate of the population proportion?
questions.explanation: For a proportion near <math><mn>0.5</mn></math>, margin of error is approximately proportional to <math><msqrt><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>n</mi></mfrac></msqrt></math>. Doubling <math><mi>n</mi></math> multiplies the margin of error by <math><msqrt><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac></msqrt></math>, which is approximately <math><mn>0.71</mn></math>. So the new margin of error is about <math><mn>0.71</mn><mo>×</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>%</mo><mo>≈</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>%</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use the idea that margin of error scales like <math><msqrt><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mi>n</mi></mfrac></msqrt></math>: doubling sample size reduces margin of error by about <math><mn>30</mn><mo>%</mo></math>.
